verse_parts.text: Now all the people witnessed the thunderings, the lightning flashes, the sound of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking; and when the people saw
they trembled and stood afar off.
Then they said to Moses, “You speak with us, and we will hear; but let not God speak with us, lest we die.”
And Moses said to the people, “Do not fear; for God has come to test you, and that His fear may be before you, so that you may not sin.”
So the people stood afar off, but Moses drew near the thick darkness where God
said to Moses, “Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: ‘You have seen that I have talked with you from heaven.
with Me—gods of silver or gods of gold you shall not make for yourselves.
An altar of earth you shall make for Me, and you shall sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings, your sheep and your oxen. In every place where I
cause My name to be remembered
record My name I will come to you, and I will bless you.
And if you make Me an altar of stone, you shall not build it of hewn stone; for if you use your tool on it, you have profaned it.
Nor shall you go up by steps to My altar, that your nakedness may not be exposed on it.’

verses.text: If you buy a Hebrew servant, he shall serve six years; and in the seventh he shall go out free and pay nothing.

tended to thrust with its horn in times past, and it has been made known to his owner, and he has not kept it confined, so that it has killed a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned and its owner also shall be put to death.
If there is imposed on him a sum of money, then he shall pay to redeem his life, whatever is imposed on him.
Whether it has gored a son or gored a daughter, according to this judgment it shall be done to him.
If the ox gores a male or female servant, he shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shall be stoned.
“And if a man opens a pit, or if a man digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls in it,
the owner of the pit shall make
good; he shall give money to their owner, but the dead
“If one man’s ox hurts another’s, so that it dies, then they shall sell the live ox and divide the money from it; and the dead
Or if it was known that the ox tended to thrust in time past, and its owner has not kept it confined, he shall surely pay ox for ox, and the dead animal shall be his own.

verses.text: “If a man steals an ox or a sheep, and slaughters it or sells it, he shall restore five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.
parts: “If a man steals an ox or a sheep, and slaughters it or sells it, he shall restore five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.

verses.text: If the thief is found breaking in, and he is struck so that he dies, there shall be no guilt for his bloodshed.
parts: If the thief is found breaking in, and he is struck so that he dies,
no guilt for his bloodshed.

verses.text: If the sun has risen on him, there shall be guilt for his bloodshed. He should make full restitution; if he has nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.

guilt for his bloodshed. He should make full restitution; if he has nothing, then he shall be sold
for his theft.

verses.text: If the theft is certainly found alive in his hand, whether it is an ox or donkey or sheep, he shall restore double.
parts: If the theft is certainly found alive in his hand, whether it is an ox or donkey or sheep, he shall restore double.

verses.text: “If a man causes a field or vineyard to be grazed, and lets loose his animal, and it feeds in another man’s field, he shall make restitution from the best of his own field and the best of his own vineyard.
parts: “If a man causes a field or vineyard to be grazed, and lets loose his animal, and it feeds in another man’s field, he shall make restitution from the best of his own field and the best of his own vineyard.

verses.text: “If fire breaks out and catches in thorns, so that stacked grain, standing grain, or the field is consumed, he who kindled the fire shall surely make restitution.
parts: “If fire breaks out and catches in thorns, so that stacked grain, standing grain, or the field is consumed, he who kindled the fire shall surely make restitution.

verses.text: “If a man delivers to his neighbor money or articles to keep, and it is stolen out of the man’s house, if the thief is found, he shall pay double.
parts: “If a man delivers to his neighbor money or articles to keep, and it is stolen out of the man’s house, if the thief is found, he shall pay double.

verses.text: If the thief is not found, then the master of the house shall be brought to the judges to see whether he has put his hand into his neighbor’s goods.
parts: If the thief is not found, then the master of the house shall be brought to the judges
whether he has put his hand into his neighbor’s goods.

verses.text: “For any kind of trespass, whether it concerns an ox, a donkey, a sheep, or clothing, or for any kind of lost thing which another claims to be his, the cause of both parties shall come before the judges; and whomever the judges condemn shall pay double to his neighbor.
parts: “For any kind of trespass,
an ox, a donkey, a sheep, or clothing,
for any kind of lost thing which
claims to be his, the cause of both parties shall come before the judges;
whomever the judges condemn shall pay double to his neighbor.

with it, he shall not make

hired, it came for its hire.

parts: If her father utterly refuses to give her to him, he shall pay money according to the bride-price of virgins.

verses.text: “You shall not permit a sorceress to live.
parts: “You shall not permit a sorceress to live.

verses.text: “Whoever lies with an animal shall surely be put to death.
parts: “Whoever lies with an animal shall surely be put to death.

only, he shall be utterly destroyed.

stranger nor oppress him, for you were strangers in the land of Egypt.

verses.text: “You shall not afflict any widow or fatherless child.
parts: “You shall not afflict any widow or fatherless child.

verses.text: If you afflict them in any way, and they cry at all to Me, I will surely hear their cry;
parts: If you afflict them in any way,
they cry at all to Me, I will surely hear their cry;

parts: “If you lend money to

verses.text: “You shall not circulate a false report. Do not put your hand with the wicked to be an unrighteous witness.
parts: “You shall not circulate a false report. Do not put your hand with the wicked to be an unrighteous witness.

verses.text: You shall not follow a crowd to do evil; nor shall you testify in a dispute so as to turn aside after many to pervert justice.
parts: You shall not follow a crowd to do evil; nor shall you testify in a dispute so as to turn aside after many to pervert

verses.text: You shall not show partiality to a poor man in his dispute.
parts: You shall not show partiality to a poor man in his dispute.

verses.text: “If you meet your enemy’s ox or his donkey going astray, you shall surely bring it back to him again.
parts: “If you meet your enemy’s ox or his donkey going astray, you shall surely bring it back to him again.

verses.text: If you see the donkey of one who hates you lying under its burden, and you would refrain from helping it, you shall surely help him with it.
parts: If you see the donkey of one who hates you lying under its burden, and you would refrain from helping it, you shall surely help him with it.

verses.text: “You shall not pervert the judgment of your poor in his dispute.
parts: “You shall not pervert the judgment of your poor in his dispute.

verses.text: Keep yourself far from a false matter; do not kill the innocent and righteous. For I will not justify the wicked.
parts: Keep yourself far from a false matter; do not kill the innocent and righteous. For I will not justify the wicked.

verses.text: And you shall take no bribe, for a bribe blinds the discerning and perverts the words of the righteous.
parts: And you shall take no bribe, for a bribe blinds the discerning and perverts the words of the righteous.

verses.text: “Also you shall not oppress a stranger, for you know the heart of a stranger, because you were strangers in the land of Egypt.
parts: “Also you shall not oppress a
stranger, for you know the heart of a stranger, because you were strangers in the land of Egypt.

verses.text: “Six years you shall sow your land and gather in its produce,
parts: “Six years you shall sow your land and gather in its produce,

verses.text: but the seventh year you shall let it rest and lie fallow, that the poor of your people may eat; and what they leave, the beasts of the field may eat. In like manner you shall do with your vineyard and your olive grove.
parts: but the seventh
you shall let it rest and lie fallow, that the poor of your people may eat; and what they leave, the beasts of the field may eat. In like manner you shall do with your vineyard
your
olive grove.

verses.text: Six days you shall do your work, and on the seventh day you shall rest, that your ox and your donkey may rest, and the son of your female servant and the stranger may be refreshed.
parts: Six days you shall do your work, and on the seventh day you shall rest, that your ox and your donkey may rest, and the son of your female servant and the stranger may be refreshed.

verses.text: “And in all that I have said to you, be circumspect and make no mention of the name of other gods, nor let it be heard from your mouth.
parts: “And in all that I have said to you, be circumspect and make no mention of the name of other gods, nor let it be heard from your mouth.

verses.text: “Three times you shall keep a feast to Me in the year:
parts: “Three times you shall keep a feast to Me in the year:

verses.text: You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread (you shall eat unleavened bread seven days, as I commanded you, at the time appointed in the month of Abib, for in it you came out of Egypt; none shall appear before Me empty);
parts: You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread (you shall eat unleavened bread seven days, as I commanded you, at the time appointed in the month of Abib, for in it you came out of Egypt; none shall appear before Me empty);

verses.text: and the Feast of Harvest, the firstfruits of your labors which you have sown in the field; and the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you have gathered in the fruit of your labors from the field.
parts: and the Feast of Harvest, the firstfruits of your labors which you have sown in the field; and the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you have gathered in
your labors from the field.

verses.text: “Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord .
parts: “Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord

verses.text: “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread; nor shall the fat of My sacrifice remain until morning.
parts: “You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread; nor shall the fat of My
sacrifice remain until morning.

verses.text: The first of the firstfruits of your land you shall bring into the house of the  your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.
parts: The first of the firstfruits of your land you shall bring into the house of the
your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.

verses.text: “Behold, I send an Angel before you to keep you in the way and to bring you into the place which I have prepared.
parts: “Behold, I send an Angel before you to keep you in the way and to bring you into the place which I have prepared.

verses.text: Beware of Him and obey His voice; do not provoke Him, for He will not pardon your transgressions; for My name is in Him.
parts: Beware of Him and obey His voice; do not provoke Him, for He will not pardon your transgressions; for My name
in Him.

verses.text: But if you indeed obey His voice and do all that I speak, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries.
parts: But if you indeed obey His voice and do all that I speak, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries.

verses.text: For My Angel will go before you and bring you in to the Amorites and the Hittites and the Perizzites and the Canaanites and the Hivites and the Jebusites; and I will cut them off.
parts: For My Angel will go before you and bring you in to the Amorites and the Hittites and the Perizzites and the Canaanites and the Hivites and the Jebusites; and I will
cut them off.

verses.text: You shall not bow down to their gods, nor serve them, nor do according to their works; but you shall utterly overthrow them and completely break down their sacred pillars.
parts: You shall not bow down to their gods, nor serve them, nor do according to their works; but you shall utterly overthrow them and completely break down their
pillars.

verses.text: “So you shall serve the  your God, and He will bless your bread and your water. And I will take sickness away from the midst of you.
parts: “So you shall serve the
your God, and He will bless your bread and your water. And I will take sickness away from the midst of you.

verses.text: No one shall suffer miscarriage or be barren in your land; I will fulfill the number of your days.
parts: No one shall suffer miscarriage or be barren in your land; I will fulfill the number of your days.

verses.text: “I will send My fear before you, I will cause confusion among all the people to whom you come, and will make all your enemies turn their backs to you.
parts: “I will send My fear before you, I will cause confusion among all the people to whom you come, and will make all your enemies turn
backs to you.

verses.text: And I will send hornets before you, which shall drive out the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite from before you.
parts: And I will send hornets before you, which shall drive out the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite from before you.

verses.text: I will not drive them out from before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the beasts of the field become too numerous for you.
parts: I will not drive them out from before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the beasts of the field become too numerous for you.

verses.text: Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you have increased, and you inherit the land.
parts: Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you have increased, and you inherit the land.

verses.text: And I will set your bounds from the Red Sea to the sea, Philistia, and from the desert to the River. For I will deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and you shall drive them out before you.

bounds from the Red Sea to the sea, Philistia, and from the desert to the

parts: You shall make no
covenant with them, nor with their gods.

verses.text: They shall not dwell in your land, lest they make you sin against Me. For if you serve their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.”

rested on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days. And on the seventh day He called to Moses out of the midst of the cloud.

. And he rose early in the morning, and built an altar at the foot of the mountain, and twelve pillars according to the twelve tribes of Israel.

And Moses took half the blood and put
in basins, and half the blood he sprinkled on the altar.

Then Moses went up, also Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel,
and they saw the God of Israel. And
under His feet as it were a paved work of sapphire stone, and it was like the very
But on the nobles of the children of Israel He did not

said to Moses, “Come up to Me on the mountain and be there; and I will give you tablets of stone, and the law and commandments which I have written, that you may teach them.”
So Moses arose with his assistant Joshua, and Moses went up to the mountain of God.
And he said to the elders, “Wait here for us until we come back to you. Indeed, Aaron and Hur
with you. If any man has a difficulty, let him go to them.”
Then Moses went up into the mountain, and a cloud covered the mountain.
rested on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days. And on the seventh day He called to Moses out of the midst of the cloud.

spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.text: “Speak to the children of Israel, that they bring Me an offering. From everyone who gives it willingly with his heart you shall take My offering.
parts: “Speak to the children of Israel, that they bring Me an
offering. From everyone who gives it willingly with his heart you shall take My offering.

verses.text: And this is the offering which you shall take from them: gold, silver, and bronze;
parts: And this
the offering which you shall take from them: gold, silver, and bronze;

verses.text: blue, purple, and scarlet thread, fine linen, and goats’ hair;

fine linen, and goats’

that I may dwell among them.

verses.text: “And they shall make an ark of acacia wood; two and a half cubits shall be its length, a cubit and a half its width, and a cubit and a half its height.
parts: “And they shall make an ark of acacia wood; two and a half cubits
its length, a cubit and a half its width, and a cubit and a half its height.

verses.text: And you shall overlay it with pure gold, inside and out you shall overlay it, and shall make on it a molding of gold all around.
parts: And you shall overlay it with pure gold, inside and out you shall overlay it, and shall make on it a molding of gold all around.

verses.text: You shall cast four rings of gold for it, and put them in its four corners; two rings shall be on one side, and two rings on the other side.
parts: You shall cast four rings of gold for it, and put
in its four corners; two rings
on one side, and two rings on the other side.

verses.text: And you shall make poles of acacia wood, and overlay them with gold.
parts: And you shall make poles
acacia wood, and overlay them with gold.

verses.text: You shall put the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark, that the ark may be carried by them.
parts: You shall put the poles into the rings on the sides of the ark, that the ark may be carried by them.

verses.text: The poles shall be in the rings of the ark; they shall not be taken from it.
parts: The poles shall be in the rings of the ark; they shall not be taken from it.

verses.text: And you shall put into the ark the Testimony which I will give you.
parts: And you shall put into the ark the Testimony which I will give you.

verses.text: “You shall make a mercy seat of pure gold; two and a half cubits shall be its length and a cubit and a half its width.
parts: “You shall make a mercy seat of pure gold; two and a half cubits
its length and a cubit and a half its width.

verses.text: And you shall make two cherubim of gold; of hammered work you shall make them at the two ends of the mercy seat.
parts: And you shall make two cherubim of gold; of hammered work you shall make them at the two ends of the mercy seat.

verses.text: Make one cherub at one end, and the other cherub at the other end; you shall make the cherubim at the two ends of it of one piece with the mercy seat.

with the mercy seat.

verses.text: And the cherubim shall stretch out their wings above, covering the mercy seat with their wings, and they shall face one another; the faces of the cherubim shall be toward the mercy seat.

wings above, covering the mercy seat with their wings, and they shall face one another; the faces of the cherubim
toward the mercy seat.

verses.text: You shall put the mercy seat on top of the ark, and in the ark you shall put the Testimony that I will give you.
parts: You shall put the mercy seat on top of the ark, and in the ark you shall put the Testimony that I will give you.

verses.text: And there I will meet with you, and I will speak with you from above the mercy seat, from between the two cherubim which are on the ark of the Testimony, about everything which I will give you in commandment to the children of Israel.
parts: And there I will meet with you, and I will speak with you from above the mercy seat, from between the two cherubim which
on the ark of the Testimony, about everything which I will give you in commandment to the children of Israel.

verses.text: “You shall also make a table of acacia wood; two cubits shall be its length, a cubit its width, and a cubit and a half its height.

its length, a cubit its width, and a cubit and a half its height.

verses.text: And you shall make for it four rings of gold, and put the rings on the four corners that are at its four legs.

at its four legs.

verses.text: You shall make its dishes, its pans, its pitchers, and its bowls for pouring. You shall make them of pure gold.

verses.text: And you shall set the showbread on the table before Me always.

verses.text: You shall make its horns on its four corners; its horns shall be of one piece with it. And you shall overlay it with bronze.

verses.text: You shall put it under the rim of the altar beneath, that the network may be midway up the altar.

verses.text: And you shall make poles for the altar, poles of acacia wood, and overlay them with bronze.

verses.text: The poles shall be put in the rings, and the poles shall be on the two sides of the altar to bear it.

on his head, and anoint him.
Then you shall bring his sons and put tunics on them.

paragraphs_list.text: Making the Altar of Burnt Offering

verse_parts.text: He made the altar of burnt offering of acacia wood; five cubits
its length and five cubits its width—
He made its horns on its four corners; the horns were
with it. And he overlaid it with bronze.
He made all the utensils for the altar: the pans, the shovels, the basins, the forks, and the firepans; all its utensils he made of bronze.
And he made a grate of bronze network for the altar, under its rim, midway from the bottom.
He cast four rings for the four corners of the bronze grating,
And he made the poles of acacia wood, and overlaid them with bronze.
Then he put the poles into the rings on the sides of the altar, with which to bear it. He made the altar hollow with boards.
He made the laver of bronze and its base of bronze, from the bronze mirrors of the serving women who assembled at the door of the tabernacle of meeting.

verses.text: Then the  spoke to Moses, saying:
parts: Then the
spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.text: “On the first day of the first month you shall set up the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
parts: “On the first day of the first month you shall set up the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.

verses.text: You shall put in it the ark of the Testimony, and partition off the ark with the veil.
parts: You shall put in it the ark of the Testimony, and
partition off the ark with the veil.

verses.text: You shall bring in the table and arrange the things that are to be set in order on it; and you shall bring in the lampstand and light its lamps.
parts: You shall bring in the table and arrange the things that are to be set in order on it; and you shall bring in the lampstand and
light its lamps.

verses.text: You shall also set the altar of gold for the incense before the ark of the Testimony, and put up the screen for the door of the tabernacle.
parts: You shall also set the altar of gold for the incense before the ark of the Testimony, and put up the screen for the door of the tabernacle.

verses.text: Then you shall set the altar of the burnt offering before the door of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
parts: Then you shall set the altar of the burnt offering before the door of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.

verses.text: And you shall set the laver between the tabernacle of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
parts: And you shall set the laver between the tabernacle of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.

verses.text: You shall set up the court all around, and hang up the screen at the court gate.
parts: You shall set up the court all around, and hang up the screen at the court gate.

verses.text: “And you shall take the anointing oil, and anoint the tabernacle and all that is in it; and you shall hallow it and all its utensils, and it shall be holy.
parts: “And you shall take the anointing oil, and anoint the tabernacle and all that
in it; and you shall hallow it and all its utensils, and it shall be holy.

verses.text: You shall anoint the altar of the burnt offering and all its utensils, and consecrate the altar. The altar shall be most holy.
parts: You shall anoint the altar of the burnt offering and all its utensils, and consecrate the altar. The altar shall be most holy.

verses.text: And you shall anoint the laver and its base, and consecrate it.
parts: And you shall anoint the laver and its base, and consecrate it.

verses.text: “Then you shall bring Aaron and his sons to the door of the tabernacle of meeting and wash them with water.
parts: “Then you shall bring Aaron and his sons to the door of the tabernacle of meeting and wash them with water.

verses.text: You shall put the holy garments on Aaron, and anoint him and consecrate him, that he may minister to Me as priest.
parts: You shall put the holy garments on Aaron, and anoint him and consecrate him, that he may minister to Me as priest.

verses.text: And you shall bring his sons and clothe them with tunics.
parts: And you shall bring his sons and clothe them with tunics.

verses.text: You shall anoint them, as you anointed their father, that they may minister to Me as priests; for their anointing shall surely be an everlasting priesthood throughout their generations.”
parts: You shall anoint them, as you anointed their father, that they may minister to Me as priests; for their anointing shall surely be an everlasting priesthood throughout their generations.”

verse_parts.text: “On the first day of the first month you shall set up the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
You shall put in it the ark of the Testimony, and
partition off the ark with the veil.
You shall bring in the table and arrange the things that are to be set in order on it; and you shall bring in the lampstand and
You shall also set the altar of gold for the incense before the ark of the Testimony, and put up the screen for the door of the tabernacle.
Then you shall set the altar of the burnt offering before the door of the tabernacle of the tent of meeting.
And you shall set the laver between the tabernacle of meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
You shall set up the court all around, and hang up the screen at the court gate.
“And you shall take the anointing oil, and anoint the tabernacle and all that
in it; and you shall hallow it and all its utensils, and it shall be holy.
You shall anoint the altar of the burnt offering and all its utensils, and consecrate the altar. The altar shall be most holy.
And you shall anoint the laver and its base, and consecrate it.
“Then you shall bring Aaron and his sons to the door of the tabernacle of meeting and wash them with water.
You shall put the holy garments on Aaron, and anoint him and consecrate him, that he may minister to Me as priest.
And you shall bring his sons and clothe them with tunics.
You shall anoint them, as you anointed their father, that they may minister to Me as priests; for their anointing shall surely be an everlasting priesthood throughout their generations.”
Thus Moses did; according to all that the
had commanded him, so he did.

content_parts.text: —According to Hebrew and Christian tradition, Moses is the author of Exodus.
This is the teaching of Christ (
—Exodus, which means “departure,” was written during the forty years of Israel's wandering in the wilderness, from the crossing of the Red Sea to the entrance into the land of Canaan.
God's covenant with Israel and the judgment of her oppressors.
God's covenant with Israel and the judgment of her oppressors.
God reveals Himself and His Name “YAHWEH,” meaning “I AM the Existing One.”
—Exodus immediately follows in the timeline after Genesis.
God brought about a series of miracles to release His people from slavery in Egypt.
The nation of Egypt was judged by God for its treatment of the Hebrews and its rejection of Him as the One True God.
The forty years of wandering in the wilderness is the consequence of Israel's sins, as well as a necessary time of preparation to inherit the promised land as a people set apart for God.

lessons.title: C H R I S T O U R P A S S O V E R

parts: Passover, the central rite and symbol of Judaism, is based on the experience of the liberation of the Hebrew people from bondage in Egypt (

). It is called Passover both because the Lord passed over the homes of the Hebrews, sparing them from the death that came to the first-born in Egypt, and because the Hebrews passed over the Red Sea as if it were dry land. Passover celebrates God’s steadfast love and devotion to His people and their freedom in Him.

Throughout the rest of the Old Testament, Passover preeminently signifies God’s rescue and forging together of His chosen people, Israel. The Lord repeatedly brings this event to mind as He encourages and exhorts His people to return to their covenantal responsibilities (

Through His saving work, Christ becomes our Passover (pascha in Greek). Through Him we experience liberation from sin, death, and the devil. St. Paul exclaims, “Christ, our Passover, was sacrificed for us. Therefore let us keep the feast” (1
, 8). He is the Paschal Lamb (
) who gave Himself up in sacrifice “once for all” (
) to reconcile us with God. At every Pascha—“Easter”—the Church sings:
Today a sacred Pascha is revealed to us, a new and holy Pascha, a mystical Pascha, a Pascha worthy of veneration, a Pascha which is Christ the Redeemer.
In many typological details, the Passover of the Jews clearly points towards Christ as our Passover.
1 The Passover lamb, whose blood was smeared by the Hebrews on their doorposts in the sign of the Cross, was a male without blemish; Jesus was a male without blemish who died on the Cross.
2 The blood of the Passover lamb saved the first-born of the Hebrews from death; the blood of Christ saves all those believing in Him from eternal death (
3 The Passover lamb had none of its bones broken (
, 46); Jesus also had no bones broken as He was sacrificed (

4 The Hebrews escaped from the burden of slavery in Egypt by passing through the Red Sea; Christians pass “from Egypt, from the burden of sin,” being “set free and saved” through the waters of Holy Baptism (GrgNy). For in the waters of Baptism, we are “baptized into His death,” “crucified with Him,” and raised up “in the likeness of His resurrection” to “walk in newness of life” (
St. John Chrysostom marvels at the power of Christ’s blood:

If the type of it had such great power . . . in the midst of Egypt, when smeared on the doorposts, much more the reality. . . . if death so shuddered at the shadow, tell me how would it not have dreaded the very reality? This blood is the salvation of our souls; by it the soul is washed, and made beautiful and . . . more gleaming than gold (see
Sustained and strengthened by the blood of Christ our Passover, we resume daily our journey to the eternal promised land, the promised kingdom to come.

lessons.title: T H E G R A C E O F C H R I S TA N D T H E L A W O F M O S E S

parts: The Apostle John wrote, “The law was given through Moses, but grace and truth came through Jesus Christ” (
). The grace of Christ and the Law of Moses are complementary, not contradictory. The following helps explain both.
Christ and Moses were friends and conversed as friends. The pre-incarnate Christ gave Moses the Law; in turn, Moses gave it to Israel (
). As the Lawgiver, Christ, not Moses, was the Author of the Law. Moses was His servant.
In the New Testament, Moses and Elijah appeared with Christ on the Mount of Transfiguration, and they conversed with Him as friend with friend (
). The presence of Moses shows Christ as the fulfillment of the Law. The presence of Elijah shows Christ as the fulfillment of the Prophets.

Christ is incomparably greater than Moses, for Christ, the Son of God, who brought all creation into existence from nonexistence, is building His Church. When Christ gave Moses and Israel the Law, He spoke as the Lord their God. Moses, however, spoke to Israel in the name of the Lord their God, not in his own name (

). When the Son of God became incarnate, He continued to speak to Israel, but now directly and not through a prophet. Although during His three-year ministry in Israel, He did works and spoke words in His almighty power, Israel refused to believe Him, their own Lord God. But to those Jews who did believe, He gave authority to become His children (

Christ also gave authority to believing Gentiles to become His children. In the Old Testament, He made it clear through Moses and His prophets the Gentiles would be included in promises to Israel (for example,
, 6). Both would be in His Church. Race is not the issue, but rather faith in Christ. His Church is one, composed of every nation, tongue and tribe (

Christ is the Lawgiver in both Old and New Testaments. Therefore, there is no opposition or contradiction between the old and new laws. In His Incarnation, the Lawgiver Himself fulfilled the old Law, making it obsolete (
Christ gave His written Law through Moses to make sin known (

). Man’s God-given natural law, written in the conscience, was dulled through disobedience in the years between Adam and Moses. The Mosaic Law helped renew this knowledge of sin to lead man to repentance. After His Ascension, Christ sent the Holy Spirit at Pentecost to convict the world of sin (
), to renew the natural law in man’s conscience (
), to lead us into all truth (
), and to make it possible for us to become partakers of the divine nature (2
Christ is the Incarnate Lawgiver who offers us remission of sins through His precious blood. The old Law could never remit sins (
). Christ not only forgives sins, but also heals the damage done through sinning. This is the unspeakable grace of the Lawgiver.

lessons.title: I M A G E S A N D I M A G E R Y

parts: Many people have been taught that the second of the Ten Commandments prohibits icons. However, if correct, all artistic representations of anything would be forbidden. The Lord Himself in the same book of Exodus commanded Moses to make two gold cherubim (angels) “of hammered work,” and to place them at each end of the mercy seat on the ark of the covenant (
). The Lord also stipulated that the ten curtains of the tabernacle be woven with images of cherubim on them (
), and likewise the veil (
When King Solomon built the temple, the huge basin, or “sea,” was set upon twelve statues of oxen (3
, 30). And upon the ten bases of the sea were cast or engraved “lions, oxen, and cherubim” (3
), as well as palm trees (3
). The Lord bestowed His blessing upon all these artistic representations first by filling the new temple with His Glory (3
, 11), and then by declaring to Solomon, “I have consecrated this house which you have built to put My name there forever, and My eyes and My heart will be there perpetually” (3

Perhaps a most striking example of an image made at God’s command in the Old Testament is the bronze serpent that God ordered Moses to make and put on a pole in order to protect the Hebrews bitten by the deadly serpents (
; see

, 15). Hundreds of years later, when the Israelites were offering incense to this same bronze serpent in a kind of idol-worship, King Hezekiah, who “did what was right in the sight of the Lord,” had the serpent smashed into pieces (4
So it is not the image itself which is faulty or prohibited, but rather its improper use. The prohibition in Exo
is not against all artistic representations. Rather, it is against images, whether in human form or not, which would be worshipped as gods and goddesses—“gods of silver, and gods of gold” (
). For the Lord knew that such images would tempt the Hebrews to depart from worshipping Him, the One true God (

Certainly, before the invisible and limitless Lord God of Israel became incarnate, it was impossible to make an image of Him. However, after God the Son assumed a visible and tangible human body, it was natural and beneficial for the Church to create artistic representations of Him—and of His holy Mother, and of the saints and angels—from the earliest times. According to tradition, St. Luke the Evangelist made at least three icons of Christ and His Mother.
Every image, or icon, of Christ has significant theological content. For it proclaims anew the Incarnation of God, who “became flesh” for our salvation (
). Recognized icons of our Savior, prayerfully made, provide us with inspired, trustworthy representations of Him.

The Seventh Ecumenical Council, held in Nicea in AD 787, condemned the heresy of iconoclasm (the rejection, and even destruction, of icons). These Holy Fathers articulated the critical distinction between the worship reserved for God alone, and the veneration/honor/ reverence given to the icons. In addition, this Council declared that “the honor given to the image passes on to that which the image represents.”

Through icons, Orthodox Christians are drawn closer to Christ. A hymn sung the first Sunday of Great Lent, which commemorates the restoration of icons in AD 843, declares: “the icons that depict Thy flesh lead us to the desire and love of Thee.”

The Hebrew word for “priest” is kohen. He is the Levite who stood as intercessor for the people before God. Old Testament priests offered up gifts and sacrifices to the Lord on behalf of the people, that they might be reconciled to Him.
The Lord directed Moses to construct the tabernacle (
). Then He established a permanent, hereditary priesthood, beginning with Moses’ brother Aaron and continuing through Aaron’s sons (
). The priests were sanctified, or consecrated, with holy oil (
). Their holy garments of finely woven and richly decorated material were for the honor and glory of God (
After Aaron’s death, “the Lord separated the tribe of Levi [Aaron’s tribe] to bear the ark of the covenant of the Lord, to stand before the Lord, to minister to Him, and to bless in His name” (
). Besides the various sacrifices, the priests blessed the people (
), maintained the tabernacle (later, the temple) and its grounds (
), received tithes and offerings (
), supervised purification procedures (
), acted as judges (
) and taught the Law (
). Only male Levites administered the liturgical rites.

From the Christian perspective, the authority of the levitical priesthood ended when Christ willingly offered Himself up to the Father as a perfect sacrifice on the cross, typified by the curtain being torn asunder in the temple (

Orthodox Christians believe the priesthood of the Church is Christ’s priesthood, with the Eucharist as the first-fruit offering. Concerning the Eucharist, St. John Chrysostom notes, “It is not men who sanctify this offering. It is the Same One who sanctified the first one [the Last Supper] who also sanctifies this one . . . Christ even now is present, and even now acts.” In the Divine Liturgy, the celebrant prays, “Thou Thyself art the One who offers and is offered, who accepts and is distributed.” The Church retains the male priesthood because the Man Christ Jesus, the Son of God, officiates at every Eucharistic service in and through His bishops, priests and deacons. The clergy do not serve in the place of Christ; rather, Christ Himself serves in them.
St. John Chrysostom marvels at how the “fearful and awe-inspiring symbols” of the leviti-cal priesthood are now “outshone by a splendor greater still” (see 2
), namely the new covenant priesthood. He writes:

When you see the Lord sacrificed and lying before you, and the priest standing over the sacrifice and praying, and all who partake being instilled with that precious blood, can you think that you are still among men and still standing on earth? Are you not at once transported to heaven? . . . He who sits above with the Father is at that moment held in our hands, and gives Himself to those who wish to clasp and embrace Him . . . how great is the honor which the grace of the Spirit has bestowed on priests.
While the ordained priesthood serves on behalf of all, every believer—baptized and anointed—is a member of God’s royal priesthood. This priestly calling of all believers is foretold in Exo
: “You shall be to Me a royal priesthood and a holy nation” (see also
), and finds its fulfillment in the Church, the new Israel: “You are . . . a royal priesthood, a holy nation” (1
; see a
, 6). Thus, all Christians are called to offer all of creation back to God, with praise and thanksgiving. And in this work, man and creation become evermore reconciled with God.

lessons.title: T H E T A B E R N A C L E

parts: On Mt. Sinai Moses received not only the Ten Commandments, but also precise and detailed instructions for building the tabernacle—a moveable tent—where God met the assembly of the people Israel (
). Consequently, the tabernacle is built according to the divine blueprints (
). Here God’s Presence, His Glory, will be made manifest through the shining cloud filling the holy place (
The importance of God’s Presence in the tabernacle is apparent in the prayers of the Psalms, which express a longing to be with God, a fervent desire to be in His tabernacle (
, 10; see a
). Indeed, the Lord promises that at the tabernacle, “I shall be known to you to speak to you. There I shall give directions to the children of Israel, and I shall be sanctified in My glory” (
; see also
). While the tabernacle is the specific place where God was encountered in Israel, this did not exhaust His Presence, for as Almighty God, He has always been everywhere present, filling all things.
Israel’s most sacred objects were kept in the ark of the covenant, located in the holy of holies (
). Each object it held was prophetic of Christ: the tablets of the Law inscribed by God (
) prefigure Christ the Lawgiver; the manna (
) points to Christ as the Bread of Life (
); and Aaron’s staff that budded (
) prefigures the life-giving Cross of Christ. Further, the veil separating the holy place from the holy of holies foreshadows the Incarnation (
The tabernacle as a whole prefigures Christ, the eternal Word of God, who “became flesh and tabernacled (the usual English translation is ‘dwelt’) among us” (
; see also

). St. Gregory of Nyssa observes, “Moses was earlier instructed by a type in the mystery of the tabernacle, which encompasses the universe. This tabernacle would be Christ, who is the power and the wisdom of God (1
).” The tabernacle also prefigures Mary the Theotokos, whose womb will be the tabernacle in which the Lord will dwell as He takes His flesh from her.
On the cross, Jesus offers the ultimate sacrifice of His body, which the New Testament calls “the greater and more perfect tabernacle not made with hands” (

). St. John Chrysostom comments that by this greater tabernacle St. Paul “means the flesh [of Christ]. And well did he say, ‘greater and more perfect,’ since God the Word and all the power of the Spirit dwell therein.”
In time, the moveable tabernacle of the wilderness is superseded by the permanent temple in Jerusalem. The temple, in turn, is superseded by Christ (
) and the Church, which is His Body (
, 23). Moreover, in Baptism every Christian becomes a tabernacle, a dwelling place of the Holy Spirit. As St. Paul exclaims, “Or do you not know that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit?” (1

). St. Isaac of Nineveh declares, “Lord, I give praise to Your holy nature, for You have made my nature a sanctuary for Your hiddenness, a tabernacle for Your Mysteries, a place where You can dwell, and a holy temple for Your divinity.”
In his vision of the kingdom of heaven, St. John writes, “But I saw no temple in it, for the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb are its temple” (
). All earthly types vanish as the redeemed behold God and the Lamb in unmediated glory (2
). The ultimate promise of the tabernacle, the temple and the Church is for God Himself to dwell in each believer forever (
; see also
